solution_line_template: The two t-shirts amount to ${tshirt_price} x {tshirt_quantity} = $<<{tshirt_price}*{tshirt_quantity}={tshirt_total}>>{tshirt_total}.
The two bags amount to ${bag_price} x {bag_quantity}= $<<{bag_price}*{bag_quantity}={bag_total}>>{bag_total}.
So Timothy spent ${tshirt_total} + ${bag_total} = $<<{tshirt_total}+{bag_total}={spent}>>{spent} for the shirts and bags.
He still has ${initial_money} - ${spent} = $<<{initial_money}-{spent}={remaining_money}>>{remaining_money} left to spend for the key chains.
With the money, he can buy ${remaining_money}/${keychain_set_price} = <<{remaining_money}/{keychain_set_price}={keychain_sets}>>{keychain_sets} sets of key chains.
Therefore, he can buy {keychain_sets} x {keychains_per_set} = <<{keychain_sets}*{keychains_per_set}={keychain_pieces}>>{keychain_pieces} pieces of key chains.
